Together, these changes will boost America‚Äôs labor movement, help create an economy that works for everyone, and put power back in the hands of working people.

I will also remake the federal courts with nominees who support working people. That starts at the top: I pledge as president to nominate a demonstrated advocate for workers to fill any Supreme Court vacancy.

Every worker should be treated with dignity and respect, and be safe in their place of employment. Any employer that fails to do so should be held accountable. My administration will expand worker protections, combat discrimination, and improve enforcement against violations.

Over the past few decades, workers have been left with fewer employment choices and less control over the companies that employ them. I'll reverse that trend by increasing worker choice and control, including requiring large companies to let workers elect board members.

My administration will raise wages for workers and protect the hard-earned pensions and retirement savings of working people. We'll start by raising the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour for all workers, including tipped workers and workers with disabilities.

Next, we'll strengthen organizing rights, make it easier for unions to assert their rights, and we‚Äôll expand the right to strike. Unions built America‚Äôs middle class, and they will rebuild the middle class.

My agenda to return power to working people starts with extending labor rights to all workers‚Äîincluding workers who have been misclassified as "independent contractors." We‚Äôll also extend basic protections to farm workers and domestic workers, including the right to organize.

We can't have a truly democratic society with so little power in the hands of working people‚Äîand we can't have sustained and inclusive economic growth without a stronger labor movement. That‚Äôs why returning power to working people will be the overarching goal of my presidency.

Giant corporations and their allies in Washington and state governments have spent decades systematically attacking unions. As more power has shifted into the hands of Wall Street managers and CEOs, it‚Äôs taken trillions of dollars out of the pockets of working families.

Even as corporate profits have soared, working families are hanging on by their fingernails. I've got a plan for the most progressive and comprehensive agenda for workers since the New Deal. http://ewar.ren/labor-tw

The St. Louis Zoo is a local treasure that brings joy to our community and their local and international conservation efforts do not go unnoticed. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EF-UtyNXYAE_oA4.jpg
Thanks to the work of the Ron Goellner Center for Hellbender Conservation, the St. Louis Zoo, and the MDC, the hellbender population has increased every year since 2011.

Missouri is the home of the only two subspecies of the hellbender salamander, also known as the giant salamander. These amphibians have suffered a serious decline in numbers over the past three decades, making the hellbender the only endangered amphibian in Missouri.

I recently met with staff of the @stlzoo and learned about Missouri's amphibian populations. The Zoo's WildCare Institute has partnered with the Missouri Department of Conservation (MDC) to help implement conservation action for the hellbender salamander.
